author: By Matthew Dallek and Robert Dallek
title: Political Violence May Be Un-American, but It Is Not Uncommon
description: The assassination attempt against Trump is one on a long list of attacks.
content: On Saturday, hours after the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump with an AR-15-style assault rifle, President Biden sounded a familiar refrain: The United States, he assured the public, settles its differences peacefully; political violence is un-American and abhorrent. “We cannot allow this to be happening,” he said. “The idea that there’s political violence or violence in America like this is just unheard-of.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Stodola
title: The Beaches of the Future Are Going to Surprise Us
description: Replenishing sand is likely to become economically untenable and logistically impractical. But that doesn’t spell the end of beaches.
content: Last December a surprise storm passed through Florida’s Pinellas County, ripping away beaches and wiping out half of the sand dunes from St. Petersburg to Clearwater. The damage was extensive, and all the more painful because the county had just spent about $26 million hauling in sand to build up the dunes after a hurricane had pummeled them in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: ‘He’s Got a Gun!’: Witness Describes Watching Shooter Get Into Position
description: The man’s voice can be heard in a bystander video that has been repeatedly featured in news reports about the assassination attempt.
content: Nathan Steadman and his daughter live not far from the farm show grounds in Butler, Pa., where former President Donald J. Trump held a campaign rally on Saturday. The two were looking to spend some time together, so they decided to check it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer, Katie Glueck and Nicholas Nehamas
title: As G.O.P. Convention Begins, ‘the Vibe Is Grim’ for Democrats
description: Worries about President Biden persist, and many see Donald Trump as electorally stronger after he survived an assassination attempt.
content: As the Republican convention opens on Monday, Democrats find themselves in a state of suspended animation and dread that the election could be tilting further away from President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Anna Foley and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: ‘I’m Just Really Glad That Trump’s OK’
description: A sense of persecution has long been core to the former president’s message — all the more so after Pennsylvania. It resonates deeply with a group of supporters for whom Jan. 6, 2021, is never far away.
content: You’ve seen the image by now: Former President Donald J. Trump has blood running down the side of his face. He’s being escorted off his rally’s stage by the Secret Service, and he pauses to look at the crowd, his fist proudly in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Dismisses Classified Documents Case Against Trump
description: Judge Aileen Cannon ruled that the entire case should be thrown out because the appointment of the special counsel who brought the case, Jack Smith, had violated the Constitution. Mr. Smith’s office said he would appeal.
content: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case threw out all of the charges against him on Monday, ruling that Jack Smith, the special counsel who filed the indictment, had been given his job in violation of the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Victoria Beckham Has Learned to Smile
description: At 50, and after some promising years for her business, the designer and former Spice Girl has softened up (a little).
content: On a balmy recent Sunday, Victoria Beckham sank into a banquette at the Fasano Fifth Avenue, a fancy hotel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, her pout a little puffier than it used to be, her slight frame sheathed in an inky silk suit of her own design. Tucked into a corner just within view was a pair of black crutches so streamlined and glossy they might have passed for an outsize accessory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Jacqueline de Jong, Rediscovered Avant-Garde Artist, Dies at 85
description: A Dutch painter, sculptor and engraver, she worked in experimental mediums, founded an influential multidisciplinary journal and enjoyed a late-career resurgence.
content: Jacqueline de Jong, a Dutch artist who was at the forefront of a 1960s avant-garde movement that critiqued postwar capitalism, and who enjoyed a career resurgence in her last decade, died on June 29 in Amsterdam. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Does It Mean to Dress Like a Zillennial?
description: Our fashion critic offers advice to a young-adult reader struggling to maintain a sense of style during a transitional period of life.
content: I’m not sure when we became so enamored of identifying ourselves by generation — somewhere after Gen X but before Gen Z, when marketing gurus got hold of the idea and the pathologizing of everything became a trend — but I am not sure it’s doing anyone any favors. It sounds to me as if what you are experiencing is not, in fact, related to the generation to which you belong, but to the life stage you are in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: staggering
description: This word has appeared in 611 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word staggering has appeared in 611 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 27 in “He Illustrated the ‘Harry Potter’ Cover for $650. It Just Sold for $1.92 Million” by John Yoon:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Don’t Lose Sight of Project 2025. That’s the Real Trump.
description: Expanding the frontiers of political cronyism.
content: I’m not going to speculate about the effect of Saturday’s attempted assassination of Donald Trump on the 2024 presidential race. I will, however, make one observation: Some on the political right are using the attack to imply that the criticism of Trump’s past efforts to overturn the results of the last election, and any suggestion that he poses a threat to democracy, is now out of bounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Julie Bosman, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Robert Chiarito and Dan Simmons
title: Protesters March in Milwaukee as Republicans Meet at National Convention
description: The demonstration, while spirited, appeared to be far smaller than organizers had expected. Some suggested that the attempted assassination of Donald J. Trump may have affected the turnout and mood.
content: Organizers had predicted that the left-leaning protesters who gathered in Milwaukee on Monday, as the Republican National Convention began, would number well into the thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: J.D. Vance Is an Oil Booster and Doubter of Human-Caused Climate Change
description: He once said society had a climate problem but changed his position sharply while seeking Donald Trump’s endorsement in his Senate race.
content: Senator J.D. Vance, Republican of Ohio, is a strong supporter of the oil and gas industry, opposes solar power and electric vehicles, and has said climate change is not a threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: At the Republican National Convention, Climate Change Isn’t a Problem
description: As the event opens with a focus on energy, former President Trump and other leaders are calling for more oil, gas and coal development.
content: Follow the latest news on Trump and the Republican National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: China Is Holding a Major Meeting on the Economy That You Can’t Watch
description: President Xi Jinping is presiding over a conclave to draft a new economic program. The stakes are high, but expectations for big changes are modest.
content: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, and 370 or so other Communist Party officials are meeting in Beijing this week, away from the public eye, to review a plan intended to shake the world’s second-biggest economy out of its malaise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media Stock Jumps as Traders Bet on His Rising Political Fortunes
description: Shares of Donald J. Trump’s social media company surged more than 30 percent on the first day of trading after the assassination attempt on the former president.
content: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company surged on the first trading day after his attempted assassination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Sizzling Day in North Dakota? Lately, It’s No Surprise.
description: At a county fair near Fargo, many residents shrugged off the heat, at least for one day.
content: After a morning filled with food and rides at a North Dakota county fair on Saturday, Bridget Bohn and her daughter, Clodagh, needed a break from the heat. They slumped on the ground in an air-conditioned building with water bottles by their sides, their cheeks flushed matching shades of red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Making Scaffolding Artful
description: A city program will offer eight designs that developers can use to make ubiquitous scaffolding more attractive.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll find out why art is coming to scaffolding on buildings in New York City. We’ll also get details on the fire commissioner’s sudden resignation over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Gambia Votes to Keep Ban on Female Genital Cutting, in Dramatic Reversal
description: Lawmakers in the West African country had supported overturning the prohibition, but changed course on Monday after a vociferous campaign led by women.
content: Lawmakers who had been moving toward repealing Gambia’s landmark ban on female genital cutting overwhelmingly changed course on Monday, voting instead to keep the legislation in place after women staged an intense three-month campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat, David French, Michelle Goldberg and Bret Stephens
title: ‘This Is the Pick of a Very Confident Presidential Nominee’: Four Columnists Size Up J.D. Vance
description: What choosing the Ohio senator as running mate tells us about Trump.
content: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat, David French, Michelle Goldberg and Bret Stephens to discuss Donald Trump’s choice of J.D. Vance as his running mate — why Mr. Trump picked him, how Mr. Vance could help the ticket, what’s surprising and unusual about the vice-presidential nominee, and what if anything worries our columnists about Mr. Vance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Trump Says He’s Revised His Convention Speech in Wake of Shooting
description: Speaking to The New York Post and The Washington Examiner, Mr. Trump said he had thrown out a “tough speech” he had planned to make at the Republican National Convention.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, in his first interviews since surviving an assassination attempt, said he had thrown out the speech that he planned to deliver at the Republican National Convention this week and was drafting one that was more unifying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $850,000 Homes in California
description: A two-bedroom bungalow with a guest cottage in Oakland, a townhouse in Novato and a renovated midcentury home in Los Angeles.
content: This house is on a quiet, tree-lined street near a public park, a few blocks from Fruitvale Elementary School. It is within walking distance of a CVS drugstore, a Safeway grocery store and a number of dining options, including a 1950s-style burger place, a French bakery and a popular Mexican restaurant. The Central Reservoir and its recreation area are less than a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: J.D. Vance on the Issues, From Abortion to the Middle East
description: Like Donald J. Trump, the Ohio senator has been skeptical of American intervention overseas and argues that raising tariffs will create new jobs.
content: Follow the latest news from Day 2 of the Republican National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Richard Simmons, Gay Icon?
description: In an era of high machismo and casual homophobia, he was a cheerleader for self-acceptance.
content: Richard Simmons, the ebullient paterfamilias of aerobics instruction who died on Saturday at 76, never publicly addressed his sexuality. But during his long run as a leading figure in American cultural life, the way he defined himself for others was perhaps less important than how he presented himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Few Lawmakers Called for Tougher Gun Laws After Trump Shooting
description: Unlike after many mass shootings, there has been no concerted outcry from elected officials to implement stricter gun safety measures.
content: When James Brady, a presidential aide, was shot during the attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan in 1981, the moment sparked a national movement to confront gun violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia Sentences U.S. Journalist in Absentia for Ukraine War Comments
description: Masha Gessen was found guilty of spreading “false information” and sentenced to eight years in prison over remarks made in 2022 about the Russian military.
content: A Moscow court on Monday sentenced in absentia Masha Gessen, the Russian-born American journalist, author and New York Times staff member, to eight years in prison over comments they made about atrocities that the Russian military has been accused of committing in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: France’s Approach to the Olympics: Food, With a Side of Games
description: The competitions can seem almost an afterthought as the country rolls out 80 pop-up restaurants and countless dining experiences to wow spectators.
content: A wing of the Eiffel Tower has been cleared out to make way for a brand-new restaurant called Gustave 24. A fully built commercial kitchen is set to be airlifted into the Palais de Tokyo, a contemporary art museum on the Right Bank. Open-air brasseries will soon be erected on two bridges across the Seine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hough
title: What I Learned About Taxes While Waiting Tables
description: Eliminating the tipped minimum wage and raising the minimum wage for all workers would help working people far more than a tax cut on tipped wages.
content: My first job was at Harrigan’s Grill & Bar in Amarillo, Texas. I was 7 years old. My mom waited tables and, like many single mothers, didn’t have child care when Grandma wasn’t available. So after school, on school holidays and weekends, my little brother and I would hang out at the restaurant until her shift ended. The other servers would pay us a few dollars in quarters to roll silverware, fill ketchup bottles, pick stray kale out of the salad bar, all the side work that had to be done before they could go home, before our mom could take us home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Spanish Police Find Body Where British Teenager Disappeared
description: Jay Slater disappeared on the Spanish island of Tenerife last month. A missing persons group said Monday that a body had been found with his possessions.
content: The Spanish authorities said on Monday that they had found the remains of a young man on the island of Tenerife, in the area where a British teenager, Jay Slater, disappeared last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: How to Watch Biden’s NBC Interview
description: The interview, which will be broadcast unedited, was planned before the assassination attempt against former President Donald J. Trump.
content: President Biden is scheduled to do a prime-time interview on Monday with Lester Holt of NBC News. The interview, which was planned before the assassination attempt on Saturday against former President Donald J. Trump, is part of Mr. Biden’s effort to stabilize his campaign after his poor performance at last month’s debate spurred doubts about his candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: With Rivals Restricted, Kagame Looks Set for Another Term in Rwanda
description: The Central African nation is voting on a potential fourth term for President Paul Kagame. Opposition figures say they have been threatened and arbitrarily detained.
content: The winding roads to this town in northern Rwanda were lined with election posters for the man who has been president for decades: Paul Kagame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Picked J.D. Vance as His Running Mate
description: Also, the Secret Service is under scrutiny. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Donald Trump announced today that he had selected J.D. Vance as his running mate, elevating the 39-year-old Senator and former Marine who transformed over the last few years from a sharp critic of the former president into one of his most loyal allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Maldonado
title: A Brooklyn Artist and the Possibilities He Seeks in Work and Life
description: After more than 40 years in a Williamsburg loft, Noah Jemison says the benefits of his tenure have come with a world of changes outside his windows.
content: Noah Jemison spent his life teaching himself to see truth, or as he put it, “the reality that exists underneath” the surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Why Everything Bagel Seasoning Was Banned in South Korea
description: The seasoning is sold by Trader Joe’s, a brand whose popularity has skyrocketed in the region in recent years.
content: The seasoning garnishes everything from bagels and scrambled eggs to fried chicken in many countries. But in South Korea, it tops something else: a list of unexpected goods travelers are banned from bringing into the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed’s Powell Welcomes Cooler Inflation but Steers Clear of Rate Cut Timing
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, avoided signaling when the Fed would cut rates at a time when some economists are wondering why officials would wait.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, avoided sending a clear signal about when the central bank would begin to cut interest rates even as he welcomed a recent cool-down in inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Simon Johnson, Julie Bosman, Vivian Yee, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Biden Calls For Calm, and a Defiant Trump Prepares for the R.N.C.
description: Plus, how cord blood banks mislead parents.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Noriko Hayashi
title: The Book Bag That Binds Japanese Society
description: No rule requires Japan’s elementary school students to wear the boxy, bulky backpack known as the randoseru. But for nearly 150 years, nearly all of them have.
content: In Japan, cultural expectations are repeatedly drilled into children at school and at home, with peer pressure playing as powerful a role as any particular authority or law. On the surface, at least, that can help Japanese society run smoothly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Botti, Malachy Browne, Haley Willis, Riley Mellen and Dmitriy Khavin
title: Bystanders Warned Law Enforcement of the Gunman Two Minutes Before He Began Shooting, Video Shows
description: People at the rally in Pennsylvania pointed to the suspected shooter two minutes before gunfire rang out, according to an analysis by The New York Times.
content: Video taken by a bystander shows people pointing to the man suspected of shooting at former President Donald J. Trump at a rally in Pennsylvania and frantically warning law enforcement, just two minutes before the first burst of gunfire rang out, according to an analysis of the footage by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Shots rang out at a Trump rally on Saturday night. The former president clutched his right ear, spurting blood, then ducked for cover as his supporters screamed and Secret Service agents leaped on top of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Nicole Hong, Jack Healy and Steve Eder
title: Trump Rally Gunman ‘Didn’t Want Attention’ in School, Classmates Said
description: Fellow students described the gunman, Thomas Crooks, as intelligent but solitary, someone who tried to avoid teasing by his classmates.
content: Before he climbed onto a rooftop and added his name to America’s bloody history of would-be presidential assassins, Thomas Crooks, 20, seemed to try to shrink from view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Christine Hauser and Sara Ruberg
title: Fires in Southern California Burn 30,000 Acres and Force Evacuations
description: In Kern and San Luis Obispo counties, multiple wildfires have forced over 1,000 evacuations and briefly shut down Interstate 5 on Sunday night.
content: Heavy winds and lightning strikes over the weekend have spurred the growth of wildfires in Southern California to more than 30,000 acres by Monday and forced more than 1,000 people to evacuate their homes, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Running Mate
description: Plus, a judge dismisses a criminal case against Trump.
content: Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio, a political newcomer who was once an outspoken critic of Donald Trump, was chosen to be his candidate for vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The Good Mood in Milwaukee
description: The way Republicans at the national convention see it, somehow, everything is going their way.
content: Hello from Milwaukee, where there is So. Much. News. Read on for the top developments and a look at how the sobriety of the weekend has given way to jubilation at the Republican National Convention. Plus, the calculus behind Trump’s pick for veep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Kamala Harris Is Ready to Debate J.D. Vance, Biden Campaign Says
description: The vice president also offered her congratulations to the Ohio senator, Donald Trump’s running mate pick.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris called Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio to congratulate him on being selected as Donald J. Trump’s running mate and to express her hope that he would participate in a CBS News debate against her, according to two Biden campaign aides with knowledge of their conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Is It Too Late to Save the Southern Grasslands?
description: Southern grassland ecosystems, and nearly all the plants and animals they supported, are gone. There is hope of bringing some of them back to life.
content: Until last fall, when PBS screened “The American Buffalo,” a documentary by Ken Burns, I had no idea bison were native to Middle Tennessee, where I have lived for 37 years. I just assumed that Nashville was part of the great temperate deciduous forests that once covered much of the eastern half of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Ameera Harouda
title: They Were Told They Were in a Safe Area. Then Came the Missiles.
description: Survivors of a strike in Gaza on Saturday that Israel said had targeted Hamas’s top military leader described a scene of carnage, with fire, smoke, blood and bodies everywhere.
content: When the explosions began on Saturday, many Gazans were sitting down to meager breakfasts, or drinking tea. They were waking up their children, or walking down the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: Olympic Specials and ‘Big Brother’
description: ABC and CNN gear up for the Games. CBS airs the season premiere of the reality competition show.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, July 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reif Larsen
title: Of Demigods and Minotaurs: Greeking Out in Athens and Crete
description: On a family tour of Greece, the writer followed the small footsteps of some of ancient mythology’s biggest fans.
content: Whenever our family goes on long car rides, we’ve found that the best way to placate our children is to listen to the podcast “Greeking Out” from National Geographic Kids. Narrated by Kenny Curtis and the all-knowing, snake-loving “Oracle of Wi-Fi,” the show retells stories from ancient Greek mythology in colorful ways. After 10 seasons, our two boys have become well-versed in the minutiae of mythos. Did you know that the blind seer Tiresias was turned into a woman by Hera for seven years? I did not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: What Is Demolition Ranch, the YouTube Channel on the Gunman’s Shirt?
description: The gunman wore a T-shirt from a popular gun-themed YouTube channel. The creator said he was “just in disbelief.”
content: The last shirt worn by the 20-year-old man who attempted to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday was a T-shirt officially sold by Demolition Ranch, a gun-themed YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Homeland Security Chief Calls Trump Shooting a Security ‘Failure’
description: “An incident like this cannot happen,” Alejandro N. Mayorkas told CNN, as the Secret Service faces intense scrutiny over the assassination attempt.
content: Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro N. Mayorkas said on Monday that the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump was a “failure” of security, as the Secret Service confronts scrutiny over its efforts to protect government officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Hillbilly Elegy’ Gets a Blockbuster Sequel
description: Our critic traces J.D. Vance’s shift from bootstrap memoirist to vice-presidential candidate.
content: “I am not a senator, a governor or a former cabinet secretary,” J.D. Vance wrote on the first page of “Hillbilly Elegy,” by way of establishing his regular-guy bona fides. That was all true in 2016, when Vance was a former Marine and Yale Law School graduate with “a nice job, a happy marriage, a comfortable home and two lively dogs.” His memoir reads a little differently now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heidi Julavits
title: I Put Up a Fence in Maine. Why Did It Cause Such a Fuss?
description: The goal was to shield our house from the road, but it soon turned into something much more revealing.
content: When we bought our house in Maine 23 years ago, people welcomed us to town with tales of local mishaps and gaffes. Barns that almost burned down. Pipes that burst. The man a mile down the road who built a fence. This chatty imparting of intel functioned simultaneously as a gesture of hospitality and a comical how-not-to primer, containing valuable survival and etiquette tips. Our town of about 830 residents more than doubles in size during the summer, when part-time residents like me arrive. The fence story suggested what types of behavior on your personal property were, and were not, considered neighborly in a town where zoning ordinances are few.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Policies Offer Benefits, but Little Political Payoff, in Pennsylvania
description: As inflation worries dominate, the Biden administration is struggling to take credit for infrastructure and industrial policy in the battleground state.
content: On a blighted industrial corridor in a struggling section of Erie, Pa., a long-abandoned iron factory has been humming with activity for the first time in decades. Construction crews have been removing barrels of toxic waste, knocking down crumbling walls and salvaging rusted tin roofing as they prepare to convert the cavernous space into an events venue, advanced manufacturing hub and brewery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The New Calculus for Democrats and Donors: Is Trump Unbeatable?
description: The shooting of Donald Trump has galvanized his campaign, prompted Elon Musk to endorse him and forced Democrats to rethink plans to oust President Biden.
content: Andrew here. The attempted assassination of Donald Trump has reverberated around the world. The question for business and policy leaders, beyond the immediate implications for the election, is how to halt the increasing political violence in this nation. America’s economy and innovation may be the envy of the world, but our politics and polarized culture are not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: From Skeptic to Superfan: J.D. Vance’s Turnabout on Trump
description: He once called Donald Trump “cultural heroin” and said he feared he could be “America’s Hitler.” But over an eight-year transformation, the Ohio senator became one of his most ardent supporters.
content: Follow the latest news from Day 2 of the Republican National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Acting Is a Trick’: Anthony Hopkins on ‘Those About to Die’
description: In an interview, the actor discusses his new series, humble origins and the freedom age brings. “That gives me a tremendous amount of energy to move forward,” he said.
content: Anthony Hopkins has advice for any aspiring actor: Speak clearly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: Trading Free-Market Ideals for Protectionism, G.O.P. Goes Full Trump
description: The Republican Party is rejecting elite economic ideas in a bid for blue-collar votes, abandoning long-held free-market principles in the process.
content: Donald J. Trump’s presidency was a major turn away from the Republican Party’s long embrace of free-market economics. If the Republican platform is any indication, a second Trump term would be a near-complete abandonment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Jillian Weinberger
title: In Trump’s Moment of Maximum Influence, There Is Reason for Hope
description: David French argues “the center has to hold or we’re lost.”
content: After an assassination attempt, Donald Trump has the power to shift the course of the Republican Party, the columnist David French argues in this audio essay. He could do that by changing the way party faithful talk about the coming presidential election. “We can hope for a change, we can hope for a turn of the current,” French says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Who Is Gabbriette? Meet the Model ‘Brat.’
description: Having spent her career on the cool-girl fringes, the model rocketed to mainstream fame with a high-profile engagement and a mention from Charli XCX.
content: “Call me Gabbriette, you’re so inspired,” sings Charli XCX on “360,” the intro track to her new album “Brat,” which has become such an instant hit that it has taken over an entire season. The line is a reference to Gabbriette Bechtel, a model and singer known as Gabbriette, whose goth-light aesthetic, defiant gaze and “brat” attitude have made her an “it” girl, particularly in the era of indie-sleaze revival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Battles to Contain Russian Advances Across the Front
description: Russian forces appear to have captured Urozhaine, a southern village taken back by Ukraine last summer. In the east, they are closing in on a key supply road.
content: Russian forces over the weekend pushed into Urozhaine, a southern village won back by Ukraine last summer, the latest in a series of slow but steady advances that are reversing hard-won Ukrainian victories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A New York Official Is Filling Community Boards With Pro-Housing Members
description: New York City community boards are known for rejecting development. In Manhattan, one politician is revamping them with appointees who say they are committed to easing the housing crisis.
content: Solutions to the housing crisis often face a small but mighty roadblock: Local residents tend to resist more development in their neighborhoods, and they typically have clout.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Insider’s Guide to the Most Mouthwatering Bakeries in Paris
description: By employing creative techniques, cross-cultural flavors and heirloom grains, these six Parisian boulangeries will satisfy your cravings for the crustiest baguettes, the airiest brioches and the flakiest viennoiseries.
content: With more than 1,300 boulangeries and a profound baking culture, Paris has always been an awesome place for your morning pain au chocolat or baguette. But the lovable boulangerie de quartier might rely on additives and premixes. After a recent monthlong stay in Paris researching a book on bread, I found that a new generation of artisanal bakers across the city is replacing commercial yeasts with carefully nurtured sourdough starters, sourcing heirloom wheats stone-ground by small mills, and embracing creative techniques and cross-cultural flavors. Their creations are worth traveling for, as I happily discovered.
source.name: The New York Times
